text: It looks like the new license check by <@UCZ7VBGUD> has already caught a non-OSI-approved license in the registry: <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/31549#issuecomment-793444424|https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/31549#issuecomment-793444424>, license text: <https://github.com/ShozenD/AutocorrelationShell.jl/blob/master/LICENSE|https://github.com/ShozenD/AutocorrelationShell.jl/blob/master/LICENSE>. What to do? :grimacing:

text: I dont think we should allow this. You use this package as a dependency, and create a website. Suddenly all your end users have restrictions placed on them that they have no hope of knowing. You've made all your users into copyright infringers

elements.text: I dont think we should allow this. You use this package as a dependency, and create a website. Suddenly all your end users have restrictions placed on them that they have no hope of knowing. You've made all your users into copyright infringers

text: Most licenses have a no-warranty clause, so not sure why they need this

elements.text: Most licenses have a no-warranty clause, so not sure why they need this

text: Also this is why OSI is so strict about field of use restrictions.

elements.text: Also this is why OSI is so strict about field of use restrictions.

text: I agree, but what action should we take? Ask the developer to change the license and take the package down from the registry if they refuse to comply? <https://juliahub.com/ui/Packages/AutocorrelationShell/pj3dI/0.1.0?t=2|https://juliahub.com/ui/Packages/AutocorrelationShell/pj3dI/0.1.0?t=2> at least it doesn't seem to have registered dependencies

elements.text: I agree, but what action should we take? Ask the developer to change the license and take the package down from the registry if they refuse to comply?
https://juliahub.com/ui/Packages/AutocorrelationShell/pj3dI/0.1.0?t=2
at least it doesn't seem to have registered dependencies

text:
They are in violation of the rules that are in the readme of General 

> License: The package should have an OSI-approved software license located in the top-level directory of the package code, e.g. in a file named LICENSE or LICENSE.md.

Or was that rule just added?

elements.text:
They are in violation of the rules that are in the readme of General 

> License: The package should have an OSI-approved software license located in the top-level directory of the package code, e.g. in a file named LICENSE or LICENSE.md.

Or was that rule just added?

text: I think the rule has been added to the readme only recently

elements.text: I think the rule has been added to the readme only recently

text: And we started enforcing it in automerge yesterday night

elements.text: And we started enforcing it in automerge yesterday night

text:
Then say: _"it is no longer permitted to register non-open source (see OSI definition") packages in General. It was never intended to allow this, but the rule started being enforced only recently.
 Your options are to a) relicense this, or b) host your own registry (link to LocalRegistry?), Or c) not register it and have users install via URL. At this stage we don't have to remove/yank your old releases (though that might change) but we can if you would like)"_

elements.text:
Then say: _"it is no longer permitted to register non-open source (see OSI definition") packages in General. It was never intended to allow this, but the rule started being enforced only recently.
 Your options are to a) relicense this, or b) host your own registry (link to LocalRegistry?), Or c) not register it and have users install via URL. At this stage we don't have to remove/yank your old releases (though that might change) but we can if you would like)"_

text: We've had that rule in metadata for years, and it got missed when copying over to General.

elements.text: We've had that rule in metadata for years, and it got missed when copying over to General.

text:
Just to add some links, the rule was added to METADATA in 2015 in <https://github.com/JuliaLang/METADATA.jl/pull/3788|https://github.com/JuliaLang/METADATA.jl/pull/3788>. The text was copied over to General in Nov 2020, <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/24051|https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/24051>. 

It looks like the first version of the package in question here was registered just a couple days before that. So it’s definitely possible the author didn’t know, but I think we should still enforce the rule (politely, of course).

elements.text: Just to add some links, the rule was added to METADATA in 2015 in
https://github.com/JuliaLang/METADATA.jl/pull/3788
. The text was copied over to General in Nov 2020,
https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/24051

It looks like the first version of the package in question here was registered just a couple days before that. So it’s definitely possible the author didn’t know, but I think we should still enforce the rule (politely, of course).
